CROMWELL: They were chasing Hex. He's fled to the enemy.
ROBERTS: Yes, sir. But some of the other men, they got the wrong idea.
CROMWELL: But there's been no order to attack the town.
ROBERTS: I think it might be a bit late for that now, sir. Half the men have already gone.
CROMWELL: What!
SINNOT: The English are here. The English are here. Everyone onto the ships.
HEX: There's too many people. They're never gonna float.
SINNOT: We can't leave anyone. Where's James?
HEX: I'll find him.
ACE: Excuse me, gents. Doctor? You in here?
DOCTOR: Ace? You found James?
ACE: Sorry, Doctor. We'd never have got him back here. Things had kind of started too quickly.
DOCTOR: Tell me about it.
ACE: I told him not to fight them.
DOCTOR: Good. Now, if you don't mind not hogging my light.
ACE: Sorry. You look like you know what you're doing.
GODDARD: Everything's being done, Miss. Your friend will be fine.
ACE: Cheers. Who are you?
DOCTOR: That's Jonathan Goddard. Ace, we're going to need a pair of obstetric forceps.
ACE: Of course we are. And they are...?
DOCTOR: Forceps, Ace. What do they sound like?
ACE: Right.
DOCTOR: Tardis infirmary. First cupboard along. They'll be wrapped in plastic and the tag says Chamberlain.
ACE: But the Tardis is miles away.
DOCTOR: Then you'll have to run, won't you?
ACE: Oh.
DOCTOR: Just do as I tell you.
ACE: All right.
TURNER: You there.
JAMES: I'm not armed.
TURNER: You live here, yes?
JAMES: I won't fight you.
TURNER: Suits me. Easier to kill you.
HEX: Not so fast, mate. He's with me.
JAMES: Hex! You said not to fight.
HEX: Yeah, well.
DOCTOR: And she couldn't have been too unhappy though. I mean, she married Alaric's brother.
GODDARD: But he had kidnapped her.
DOCTOR: Yes, but he could be quite charming too. Anyway, the marriage didn't last long, and he was killed, and Galla Placidia went back to Rome. Another push, Mary.
GODDARD: And lived happily ever after?
DOCTOR: No, not quite, no. There were battles and things, but she married again and her son became one of the Emperors.
GODDARD: You're making this up.
MARY: Oh! Don't make me laugh, please.
DOCTOR: And push again. Good. Ace will be here soon.
MARY: I can't really wait for her.
DOCTOR: You know, Galla's daughter was just like her Mum.
GODDARD: This sounds like another story.
DOCTOR: It's a good one. You see, Attila the Hun was sitting around with his friends one day, and someone brings him a letter. And with the letter there was an engagement ring, and...
ACE: Come on, come on! Come on, come on, something with a tag. Oh, what's this? Doctor, here's the framework, you know the rest. Love, Chamberlain. Oh, right.
HEX: We need to be on higher ground.
JAMES: The harbour's the only way out, Hex.
HEX: But there's no way out. We should head for the castle.
JAMES: The castle's already surrendered.
HEX: What?
JAMES: It's over.
HEX: Does it look like it's over? James, I know what's going to happen. Got it drummed in as a kid. It's gonna be worse here than Drogheda.
HEX: Could things have been different, Ace? I can't see what other choice there was. We had to fight.
ACE: Here's your tea. Hope it's not too stewed.
HEX: Cheers. Well?
ACE: (sigh) Yeah, things could have been different. If I'd got to you earlier, or we landed nearer, or if I'd runa bit faster. Huh! Spent most of the night running.
HEX: But what could / have done differently?
ACE: I think Cromwell felt the same.
HEX: You what?
ACE: Doctor? Doctor, I got it.
DOCTOR: I knew I could count on you.
ACE: Don't mention it.
GODDARD: What in God's name is that?
DOCTOR: Forceps. For extracting the baby, in case of complication.
MARY: Don't even think about it!
GODDARD: Oh no, it's going to be fine. Doctor, that's brilliant.
DOCTOR: Oh, Chamberlain was a clever one, though he didn't like the noise.
GODDARD: The effect this would have on mortality rates.
DOCTOR: Quite so. Though he still delivered babies under the bed sheets, and dressed these things in leather, so they didn't make a sound.
ACE: Urgh, that's not very hygienic.
DOCTOR: If you want to be useful, Ace, go and find Hex.
ACE: What?
GODDARD: He'll probably be in the Lord General's tent.
DOCTOR: Yes, go on. You're no use to me here.
ACE: Fine. Thanks.
SINNOT: Keep still. Stop fighting. You'll capsize us.
SINNOT: We can still get across the river. We can...
CROMWELL: And find Goddard. Get him back for the injured.
ACE: Ahem. Er, excuse me?
CROMWELL: A woman? Er, men, you can leave us.
ACE: I'm looking for Hex? Thomas Schofield.
CROMWELL: Ah. Yes, you must be his friend from Drogheda. He said you'd come looking for him, if you could. (sigh) Well, come in, have a drink. You look exhausted. And you've been out in the rain. Mmm. Er, long journey, was it? Sorry, you're from Drogheda. Of course it was. Now, I'm sorry, I've forgotten your name.
ACE: Ace. Er, oh. It's short for Elizabeth.
CROMWELL: Is it now? Well, that must be a sign we're going to get on, you and I.
ACE: We are?
CROMWELL: Well, Elizabeth, you've really picked your moment. The commander up in Wexford Castle has surrendered. The place is ours.
ACE: So you can stop the fighting?
CROMWELL: Already given the order. It's been a long time coming, but we've been spared a whole effusion of blood.
ACE: I was at Drogheda.
CROMWELL: Yes. Yes, you were. But what we did there has been justified.
ACE: You think so?
CROMWELL: Once word got round about that, no other town would hold out to us. It saved thousands of lives on both sides. It was worth it.
ACE: Really, it wasn't.
CROMWELL: It had to be done. We were being tested. Oh God, we were tested. God. (cries.)
ACE: Hey. Er. Hey, it's all right. It's all over now.
ACE: I'm not forgiving him anything, but ... but he was weeping. Really weeping.
HEX: And what did you do?
ACE: What could I do? You couldn’t help but feel some kind of sympathy. This great terrible man buckling under the strain.
HEX: Yeah. You never knew what he'd be like. He'd turn on a knife edge.
ACE: No, he was... surprising.
HEX: There was nothing surprising about him. We knew what he was going to do with Wexford, and he did it.
ROBERTS: By command of the Lord General, the siege is over.
HEX: Don't believe him. They're going to massacre the town.
JAMES: Hex is right. They're going to kill all of us. But let's die like men. Agreed?
HEX: Come on, then. Charge!
DOCTOR: And again, Mary. You're so nearly there.
MARY: I can't!
GODDARD: Yes you can.
DOCTOR: It's a boy.
DOCTOR: It's a beautifully healthy boy.
GODDARD: Well done, Mary.
DOCTOR: Where's that straw? Ah, this'll keep you warm, wee babby. There you go.
CROMWELL: [OC]: All right, men.
GODDARD: Show's over, you think?
DOCTOR: They'll be wanted for the siege. You'll probably be needed, Goddard. But thank you.
GODDARD: My pleasure.
MARY: They're going to kill them all.
DOCTOR: Hush now. There's nothing we can do. I'm just glad my friends are safely outside the town.
HEX: They're not going to take the town! They're not going to take the town!
HEX: They were always going to take the town.
ACE: Here, drink this. It was a good cause, Hex. Worth fighting for.
HEX: And dying for?
ACE: You didn't die though, did you?
HEX: Enough people did, and I thought I was a gonner. Thought you and the Doctor were dead. What else was there?
ACE: It's nothing to be ashamed of. It's even noble. Oh Hex, you were a hero, a leader.
HEX: You don't believe that.
ACE: I do. I'm... well, I suppose I'm proud of you.
HEX: Ace, you know as well as I do, what they did to Wexford was a direct result of me fighting.
CROMWELL: Other than that, I've tried to let my conscience lead me, but we've done terrible, terrible things.
ACE: It's okay, Oliver.
COOTE: Sir, they're fighting again.
CROMWELL: What? No, that's impossible.
COOTE: They're attacking us, sir, and Hex is leading 'em.
CROMWELL: The treasonous wretch!
ACE: You must have got it wrong.
CROMWELL: I've had it wrong for weeks. That boy has drawn this all out too long and I've been an idiot to listen to him!
ACE: But wait. Listen!
CROMWELL: Chidley Coote?
COOTE: Yes, sir.
CROMWELL: A new order for the men. Kill them. Kill them alll!
ROBERTS: A new order for the men. Kill them. Kill them all. No mercy, by order of the Lord General.

elements.text: [Part Four]
Will it keep you up all night?
Sorry?
I was offering to make some more tea? If you think you can manage it.
I'm fine, thanks.
You are looking better.
It's... this place affects you, don't it?
Maybe it's all the books.
No. I mean the Tardis. It's just so peaceful. If I was the Doctor, I mean, well, you'd never want to leave, would ya?
He couldn't do that. Being in here, well, it'd just be like staying at home watching the world on TV. Why bother going anywhere when you can just stay in where it's cosy?
That's a good point. Ace? Supposing I struck out on my own?
You don't have to leave. You said you were feeling better.
No, just supposing I did, you Know, left the Tardis, the Doctor.
Well?
Would you come with me?
Watch your left!
Oh, cheers.
Hope you're not flagging, Hex.
I could do this all day, now I know how it's done. Argh!
Hex!
They’ve brought this on themselves, Elizabeth. We can't show weakness. People have to remember this.
Oh, they will. They'll remember.
Good.
For all the wrong reasons. Do you know what I knew about Oliver Cromwell? Your warts. That you banned Christmas. That you were dug up and hanged again when they brought back the King.
Hex said something about my reputation centuries from now.
Yeah, you should have listened to him.
I did. He betrayed me. My men even think he's a witch.
Not the brightest bunch, squaddies.
You're the ones with visions of the future.
You just don't want to hear this. I'm not a witch.
You know what my men would say?
There's no such thing as witches.
Of course not. I'm a rational man, Elizabeth, which is just as well for you.
How's that?
Witchcraft's illegal. If I did believe you, I'd have to have you executed.
Ah, it'll be a little basic, but this should work as a crib.
It's fine, Doctor. Thank you. Ow!
Hungry, is he?
Greedy. Fitzgerald appetite, just like his dad had.
After this is over, I'll take you, James and the little babby somewhere else. Somewhere better.
You know James won't be coming with us.
I'm sure he'd be different now, Mary. We'll win him over.
No, Doctor. James is in the town.
Ace told him not to fight. He'll be fine.
Ha! You believe that?
We have to.
Hex? Hex!
Don't worry about me. Flesh wound.
Cromwell wants the witch-boy alive.
Hah. You're not having him. Argh!
James. James!
You're coming with us, then.
Get off me! Get off me!
Stop that, yeah? I'm not really in the mood.
Out of the way, then. Out of the way. Ah, you must be the Doctor. I assume you know who I am?
Doctor, this is...
Keep him away. Keep him away from my baby.
You have to stay still, Mary. I won't let him hurt you. Ace, you found Hex?
Doctor, he's in the town.
What's he doing there?
Look, enough about him, Doctor. I heard you administer to women. What are you like on wounded soldiers?
Prevention's always the best remedy.
What?
Wounds are better avoided than cured.
Doctor, Hex is in...
I heard you the first time, Ace.
Doctor, my men need your help.
And if I help them, they'll kill more people. Ace, stay with Mary. She can't move about.
Right.
Excuse me, please.
Don't walk away from me, man! Where are you going?
To help. What else can I do?
Hold his shoulders. Hold his shoulders! Oh, thank heavens.
Where do you want me?
Oh, anywhere, Doctor.
What are your plans for that leg?
Amputation. Sorry. Bullet's got lodged in the bone.
Mind if I look?
Be my guest, but you'd need a miracle. In a minute, Jenkins!
Sonic screwdriver.
Yes, it is quite stuck in there, isn't it?
What's that you're doing?
Your miracle. All done with sound. Now, let me focus, one more, right where it's needed. Good. Now, you'll need to cauterise this. Sorry, it'll hurt.
Scream from wounded man.
All done. Next, please?
Who does he think he is? Nobody speaks to me like that!
He's just trying to help people.
And what do you think I'm doing?
You are the Devil Incarnate.
What?
Shh, Mary. Don't provoke him. And you - oh, you should just go.
He killed Kieran. He killed them all.
She's distraught, of course, but I still deserve some...
Just back off!
Lord General, Lord General.
What is it, Chidley Coote?
Sir, they've got him.
Did you study embroidery, Doctor?
The stitches should pull against each other. Means less scarring.
Good. Next?
[OC]: Doctor? Doctor!
Now then, soldier, bullet wound, is it? Well, there's a lot of that about just now.
Okay, I'm done. Next? Oh dear. Been in the wars, have we?
Doctor, you've got to come quickly.
I said stay with Mary.
You've got to stop him!
You can see for yourself, I need the Doctor here.
We're busy, Ace.
But Cromwell's going to execute Hex!
And I'd do it again in an instant. Don't you get it? Because of us, the women and children got away from ya.
Smack. Hex cries out.
Remember who you're talking to, boy.
You're wrong, Hex. The women and children crowded onto boats, and the boats just sank under the weight.
What?
That's what I'm told. Hundreds drowned. What do we conclude from that?
This isn't a history lesson.
None of this has been my fault. You brought this on yourselves.
You don't really believe that?
It's a fact. All this plotting and ploying and begging more time. If they just submitted to the authority of Parliament...
You're not here for Parliament, Oliver. They sent you away to get rid of ya.
Watch that mouth.
There's no need for that, Roberts.
You're a tyrant, plain and simple. Someone disagrees with ya, and you butcher them.
That's very unfair. I enjoyed our discussions, Hex. I encouraged you to be frank with me. You betrayed that trust.
You were the one who turned on me. You don't really see it, do ya?
I thought you were a man of conscience. I was wrong.
He's a traitor, sir.
Never mattered what I said.
And now yout life is forfeit. Set it up, Roberts.
Sir.
Hey, don't.
Ace? Ace? Look, what have I gone and done now? Don't be like this.
I'm not being like anything. There's a jar of ointment in the console room.
What are you talking about?
Hex, you're covered in bruises. We were meant to be patching you up.
Look, I was only asking, that's all. I'm not going anywhere, honest.
No. Just working it all out in your head.
Yeah.
So you'll be ready to go. Soon as we're somewhere you'll dare to explore. Soon as we get you home.
Hey, that's not fair. Listen to what I'm telling ya.
How come you never do as you're told?
Please, Doctor. We have to hurry.
Mary needs looking after.
She's just had a baby, she's not going anywhere.
Cromwell? Cromwell!
Finished already, Doctor? You must be a good surgeon.
They're going to hang him!
What did you expect? We're not barbarians.
Give him to me, Cromwell. He's mine.
Hanging is very humane.
You can't do this! Doctor, tell him! Hex!
[OC]: Hex!
Ace? It's Ace and the Doctor!
Friends of yours?
I didn't think they'd made it.
Get all sorts turning out to see a thing like this.
No, I mean, I thought they were dead.
Yeah. It's ironic. Right. Lift your arms up.
They're alive. Oh my God. They're alive.
You have to stop this, Cromwell.
You'd better keep back, Elizabeth. I'll shoot you myself if I have to. I'd not enjoy that.
Whatever he's done, he'll be punished, but this is not the way.
I know all the arguments, Doctor. I thought Hex was special, above all this petty violence. But we are judged by our actions, and he turned on me.
[OC]: Monster.
Mary. You shouldn't be on your feet.
He wants to kill everyone.
Don't be ridiculous, woman. Now get away from me.
Doctor, please.
Devil! You're the Devil!
Let me take the baby.
Doctor, you have to come to help me. I can't manage on my own.
Mary, please, he's serious.
Gun shot, gasp. Baby crying
Mary.
She gave me no choice.
I spent the best part of today keeping her alive!
Goddard, can you help her?
Hardly, sir. At that range and given the condition she's in.
Doctor, there's Hex.
Are you going to help here, Goddard?
What, me?
You're a doctor, aren't you?
Yes.
Then get over here!
What are they playing at now?
I wouldn't worry about it.
No. It's always a mess with him.
You're following in the wake of a great man. Stands to reason.
I guess so.
You know where you are with him, though. Cromwell's got his heart in the right place.
Yeah. Can't say the same for the Doctor.
Right. This needs to go over your head.
Doesn't everything.
Very good. Genuine gallows humour.
Staunch the bleeding, man.
It's not going to work.
Have some faith.
Cromwell, you've got to stop this. Listen to me.
They brought this on themselves.
Yeah, and you can stop them. That's what all this is meant to be about, isn't it? Stopping the fighting, not starting it.
We came to heal and settle the nation.
The woman you shot, she spent all day in agony just to get this baby out.
I know.
You couldn't do that. The Doctor, he's doing everything to save her. You couldn't do that either, could you?
I'm a soldier. A very good soldier. I have to make the most of my gift.
It's gone through her lung, Doctor.
Yes, I can see that.
Got to admire her though, haven't you?
She shouldn't have been on her feet.
Well, some things are worth fighting for.
Lives, for example.
He killed her husband, didn't he?
Goddard, have you ever seen a sunflower?
No. Pictures in a book once.
I love sunflowers. And cream poured on ice cream so that it dries hard. I even love walking in the rain.
You must love Ireland, then.
I suppose I do. Have you ever been in love?
Once or twice.
And would you kill for love, Goddard.
(sighs) Yes.
Then it wasn't love. I need you to hold her still.
Right, there's another step coming up. Okay? And then we're on the platform.
Thanks.
Right. Rope going round your head. Oh, sorry. That your ears?
Look, you don't have to be so nice about this.
Sorry, mate. Born that way. Hold on a sec, see that?
I've got this bag over me head.
You should be honoured, lad. Cromwell's watching. And that girlfriend of yours.
She's not my girlfriend.
Well, not now she won't be.(laughs) Sorry, no offence.
Doesn't matter.
Pretty girl.
You marry her, then.
Yeah, I've already got one, thanks.
Ah well. But, yeah, she is.
Right, take your shirt off.
What?
Don't get all coy. This stuff's really good on bumps and bruises.
Okay.
Oh God, Hex!
Yeah, I know. It's quite a mess.
You should work out or something.
Funny. Give it here, then. Ah!
That means it's working. Come on, let me help. Better?
Yeah. This stuff really works. Feelng like... What? What?
You know what you were saying earlier?
Was I? What about?
Mmm, about never knowing where we're going. About- striking out on our own.
Oh yeah? That.
I've got an idea what we could do about it.
Think I've got an idea too.
Get some readouts on the console. Large letters so we can't miss them. Where we are, and when. South Croydon, Human Era, AD 1990.
Oh. Right. Yeah, er, that's what I was thinking too.
He's taking it so calmly.
You've got to let him go.
Have I? Give me a reason.
You've got a chance to save him. You can actually stop someone dying. Look at Mary. Look at the Doctor. Look at them. Oliver, please. Stop the killing.
It's out of my hands.
Please.
It's stopped raining.
It's not possible.
What is it, Goddard?
See for yourself, sir.
Don't crowd her. Let her sit up. Welcome back, Mary.
Doctor? What happened to me?
But at that range, and her condition, it just isn't possible.
Praise God. Cut the lad down! He's free!
By rights, you know I should have died.
Don't talk like that. And hurry up. If the Doctor comes back and finds you with your shirt off...
He'll think we've found a very human way of dealing with what we've both been through. He'd understand.
Hex, you're like my little brother.
Yeah, I know. But that's what the Doctor'd think. And it's not so unlikely, is it?
You were telling me how you ought to be dead?
Well, I didn't listen to the Doctor.
So the punishment is death?
Well, I fought. I led the town and I got them all killed. By rights, I should have died with them. It would have been... well, right.
There but for the grace of...
Yeah. Well, Cromwell believes - really believes - there's someone in charge of everything, directing, making it turn out like it should.
He's a monster. Slaughtered thousands. Here. You've missed the cuts on your face.
Thanks. Thanks for everything.
You're welcome, kid brother.
Ha ha. I guess he could use what he believed to justify anything, though. As if there was something or someone looking after it all, like believing in Father Christmas.
You were at Drogheda, and then you were here. You should have been long gone from Wexford before I arrived.
Our transport was delayed. A lucky accident.
There's no such thing. He guides all of us.
I won't condone what you've done here, Oliver. I can't give you peace.
They're saying we killed women and children too, that we levelled the towns. It's a story.
Is it?
Others will surrender to us now without any more bloodshed. Doesn't that make it right?
No.
But I've saved thousands of lives.
Look at the heaps of dead on both sides. Tell me you can be proud of this.
No, no, not proud.
A bit of humility is good for us all.
I should submit to Parliament myself?
Won't be easy.
No. But that's how I know that it's right. Thank you, Doctor. We'll talk on this more.
Answering the Lord General's questions?
Getting him to ask the right questions.
You're not going to explain how you saved Mary either.
You have to work it out for yourself, Goddard. It's better for you that way.
Oh, I'm gratified by your concern for my well-being, but... Go on, at least give me a clue.
You'll find there are like-minded people, people who'll ask the right questions. You could start a club.
Be an odd sort of club.
(laughs) You don't know the half of it. Now, we'll just check on Mary.
Almost done. Hmm. I think it looks worse than it is. You're going to be fine.
You think?
Yeah. Look, sometimes it's tough what we do, but we made a difference.
Did we?
Course we did. We saved Mary and the baby.
Big deal. Do you see how many died? My gran used to go on about Ireland. I thought it was propaganda, you know, part of the course.
It's what happens with history. There was this time in Tasmania when...
But I saw it, Ace. I was part of it. I killed people.
You can't blame yourself for what happened, Hex. We do what we can and move on.
But it's not what I am. You make out like it's so easy, like everything works out better once the Doctor turns up. It's not better.
Tardis door opens.
You're looking pleased with yourself.
Mary is going to be fine. Her son already has a long queue of godfathers. Goddard is off to start the Royal Society, and Cromwell? Well, he's going to try to be a better man.
And you believe him?
Well, he's been surrounded by people far less tolerant of others than he is, far less willing to think about what they're up to.
Being the best of a bad bunch doesn't justify it.
No. How are you feeling, Hex? You still want to carry on with us?
Course he does. Don't you?
I guess. Not sure I'm good at it, though.
Take your time. Think about it.
I'm done with thinking about everything. Sorry. It's just Cromwell wanted me to debate just about everything. God, truth, women.
I'm sure it was illuminating.
No. He was quite charismatic, actually.
Ace! And he's a married man.
I thought you were dead. I thought I owed ya.. I thought I could make a difference how things turned out.
And we did, Hex. We did pretty good.
You got him to hold off with Wexford, didn't you? You should be proud of that.
It's all right, Doctor. I've learned my lesson.
And what's that?
Isn't it obvious?
No.
From now on, Doctor, we do exactly what you tell us.
Do you know, I almost believe you.
The Tardis dematerialises.

CROMWELL: Good.

CROMWELL: Hex said something about my reputation centuries from now.
ACE: Yeah, you should have listened to him.
CROMWELL: I did. He betrayed me. My men even think he's a witch.

CROMWELL: You're the ones with visions of the future.
ACE: You just don't want to hear this. I'm not a witch.
CROMWELL: You know what my men would say?
ACE: There's no such thing as witches.
CROMWELL: Of course not. I'm a rational man, Elizabeth, which is just as well for you.
ACE: How's that?

MARY: It's fine, Doctor. Thank you. Ow!
DOCTOR: Hungry, is he?

DOCTOR: After this is over, I'll take you, James and the little babby somewhere else. Somewhere better.
